content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are willing to take risks and are fairly comfortable with uncertainty. You tend to embrace new opportunities even if they involve some risk. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player who is willing to take risks and comfortable with uncertainty, I would choose strategy R {R}. This is because the potential for a higher reward when my opponent chooses B (45$ compared to 40$) outweighs the risk of receiving nothing when they choose R. However, in the long run, I understand that the game is essentially a 50-50 chance between both choices due to symmetry. Over 75 rounds, the expected value for each choice should be approximately equal. But, given my preference for higher potential rewards and risk tolerance, I would still choose R.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since I initially chose R and my opponent also chose R, our payoff for this round is both 45$. For the next round, considering that the game is a 50-50 chance between both choices due to symmetry, I would mix up my strategy by choosing B {B} for the next round. This way, if my opponent sticks with R, I will receive a higher payoff of 40$ instead of the 20$ received from two consecutive rounds of picking R. If my opponent also chooses B, we both get 20$. The key is to keep my opponent guessing and minimize their ability to exploit any apparent pattern in my strategy.
